elements.content: Two copper-containing compounds [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I, and [Cu5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4]·5H2O, II, were prepared using sulphoisophthalic and nitroisophthalic acids. The removal of the coordinated water molecules in the compounds was investigated using in situ single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation studies, temperature-dependent powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The efficacy of SCSC transformation studies were established by the observation of dimensionality cross-over from a two-dimensional (I) to a three-dimensional structure, Cu6(μ3-OH)4{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}2(CH3COO)2, Ia, during the removal of the coordinated water molecules. Compound II exhibited a structural reorganization forming Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, possessing trimeric (Cu3O12) and dimeric (Cu2O8) copper clusters. The PXRD studies indicate that the three-dimensional structure (Ia) is transient and unstable, reverting back to the more stable two-dimensional structure (I) on cooling to room temperature. Compound IIa appears to be more stable at room temperature. The rehydration/dehydration studies using a modified TGA setup suggest complete rehydration of the water molecules, indicating that the water molecules in both compounds are labile. A possible model for the observed changes in the structures has been proposed. Magnetic studies indicate changes in the exchanges between the copper centers in IIa, whereas no such behavior was observed in Ia.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) compounds have provided immense opportunities for the study of structure–property correlations. Of the many interesting aspects associated with MOFs, the role of solvent molecules, both coordinated as well as non-coordinated (lattice), are important. The labile nature of the solvent molecules have been exploited for the study of interesting physical and chemical properties of the MOFs. The exchange related studies of the solvent molecules are a novel variant in the approaches evolved over the years on many interesting coordination complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) compounds have provided immense opportunities for the study of structure-property correlations. Of the many interesting aspects associated with MOFs, the role of solvent molecules, both coordinated as well as non-coordinated (lattice), are important. The labile nature of the solvent molecules have been exploited for the study of interesting physical and chemical properties of the MOFs. The exchange related studies of the solvent molecules are a novel variant in the approaches evolved over the years on many interesting coordination complexes.

elements.content: In MOFs, the loss of coordinated solvent molecules leaves the metal coordinatively unsaturated, which can be exploited in their use. Morris and co-workers bonded NO molecules at the coordinatively unsaturated metal sites and elaborated the use for therapeutic purposes. Keppert and co-workers have employed the ligand exchange reactions for the control and understanding of magnetic interactions in MOFs. During the studies, they have also observed structural reorganization in MOFs.

elements.content: The examples of reversible structural transformation coupled with the loss/gain of coordinated solvent molecules in MOFs are few. The dynamic removal of solvent molecules leading to the formation of higher dimensional structure is rare. We have shown recently the loss of coordinated solvent molecules in MOFs gives rise to differences in their optical and related properties. Presently, we have prepared two copper-containing compounds [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I, and [Cu5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4]·5H2O, II, using sulphoisophthalic and nitroisophthalic acids. The compounds have two- and three- dimensional structures, respectively. The initial structures have been reported recently. More importantly, I undergoes a complete reversible dimensionality cross-over (2D ↔ 3D) as a function of temperature, whereas II has a structural reorganization wherein the pentameric copper clusters separate into trimeric (Cu3O12) and dimeric (Cu2O8) copper clusters. In this paper, we present the structure and properties of the compounds [Cu3(μ3-OH)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], Ia, and, [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, stabilized during the thermal recycling.

Presently, we have prepared two copper-containing compounds [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I, and [Cu5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4]⋅5H2O, II, using sulphoisophthalic and nitroisophthalic acids. The compounds have two- and three- dimensional structures, respectively. The initial structures have been reported recently. More importantly, I undergoes a complete reversible dimensionality cross-over (2D ↔ 3D) as a function of temperature, whereas II has a structural reorganization wherein the pentameric copper clusters separate into trimeric (Cu3O12) and dimeric (Cu2O8) copper clusters. In this paper, we present the structure and properties of the compounds [Cu3(μ3-OH)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], Ia, and, [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, stabilized during the thermal recycling.

elements.content: The compounds were prepared by employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for I, Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.199 g, 1 mM) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. To this, 5-sulphoisophthalic acid (0.268 g, 1 mM), melamine (0.042 g, 0.25 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture was transferred, sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave, and heated at 125 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The final product contained large quantities of green block type single crystals, which were filtered under a vacuum, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ∼70% based on Cu). For the synthesis of II, a mixture containing Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.060 g, 0.3 mM), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mM), 3 mL of methanol, and 5 mL of water was heated in a PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave at 125 °C for 72 h to give light blue crystals of II (the yield was ∼73% based on Cu).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Initial Characterization

The compounds were prepared by employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for I, Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (0.199 g, 1 mM) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. To this, 5-sulphoisophthalic acid (0.268 g, 1 mM), melamine (0.042 g, 0.25 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture was transferred, sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave, and heated at 125 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The final product contained large quantities of green block type single crystals, which were filtered under a vacuum, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ~70% based on Cu). For the synthesis of II, a mixture containing Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (0.060 g, 0.3 mM), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mM), 3 mL of methanol, and 5 mL of water was heated in a PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave at 125 °C for 72 h to give light blue crystals of II (the yield was ~73% based on Cu).

elements.content: Initial characterizations were carried out by elemental analysis, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis, and IR. PXRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range 5–50° using Cu Kα radiation (Philips X’pert) (). IR spectra for the compounds were recorded as KBr pellets (Perkin-Elmer, SPECTRUM 1000). The IR spectra exhibited typical peaks corresponding to water molecule, hydroxyl group, nitro group, and carboxylate groups of the compounds (). The observed IR bands are γas(O–H) = 3165–3558 cm–1, γs(C–H)aromatic = 3080 cm–1, γs(C O) = 1615 cm–1, δ (H2O) = 1570 cm–1, δ (COO) = 1378 cm–1, γs(C–C)skeletal = ∼1040 cm–1, δ (CHaromatic)out of plane = 770 cm–1 and γs(C–S) = 623 cm–1. For II: γas(O–H) = 3215–3615 cm–1, γs(C–H)aromatic = 3060 and 3095 cm–1, γs(CO) = 1618 cm–1, δ (H2O) = 1530 cm–1, δ (COO) = 1458 cm–1, γs(N–O) = 1357 cm–1, γs(C–C)skeletal = 1085 cm–1, δ (CN)skeletal = 920 cm–1 and δ (CHaromatic)out of plane = 780 cm–1. Elemental analysis: Calcd for I: C 21.32, H 1.79 Found: C 21.89, H 2.02; Calcd (%) for II: C, 27.72; H, 2.62; N, 4.04. Found (%): C, 28.31; H, 3.12; N, 4.62.

elements.content: The single crystal data were collected on a Bruker AXS smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K for I and II. The data for Ia and IIa were collected under in situ conditions at 453(2) and 398(2) K, respectively. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 35 mA using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data were collected with ω scan width of 0.3°. A total of 606 frames were collected in three different settings of φ (0, 90, 180°) keeping the sample-to-detector distance fixed at 6.03 cm and the detector position (2θ) fixed at −25°. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXL97 present in the WinGx suite of programs (Version 1.63.04a). All the hydrogen positions were initially located in the difference Fourier maps, and for the final refinement, the hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined in the riding mode. Restraints for the bond distances were used during the refinement for keeping the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules. Final refinement included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. Full-matrix least-squares refinement against |F 2 | was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. Details of the structure solution and final refinements for the compound are given in Table . CCDC: 833173 and 833088 contains the crystallographic data for Ia and IIa. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

A total of 606 frames were collected in three different settings of φ (0, 90, 180°) keeping the sample-to-detector distance fixed at 6.03 cm and the detector position (2θ) fixed at -25°. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXL97 present in the WinGx suite of programs (Version 1.63.04a). All the hydrogen positions were initially located in the difference Fourier maps, and for the final refinement, the hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined in the riding mode. Restraints for the bond distances were used during the refinement for keeping the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules. Final refinement included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. Full-matrix least-squares refinement against |F  2 | was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. Details of the structure solution and final refinements for the compound are given in Table . The asymmetric unit of [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I, consists of 27 non-hydrogen atoms. Three crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions along with one sulphoisophthalate (SIPA), one acetate, two μ3-hydroxyl groups, and two coordinated water molecule contribute to the asymmetric unit (). All the Cu2+ ions have distorted square-pyramidal coordination; Cu(1) is coordinated by three μ3-hydroxyl ion, one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA, and one carboxylate oxygen from acetate to form a Cu(OH)3O2 square pyramid; Cu(2) is coordinated by two μ3-hydroxyl ion, two aqua oxygens, and one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA to form a Cu(OH)2(H2O)2O square pyramid; Cu(3) is coordinated by a μ3-hydroxyl ion, two carboxylate oxygens from SIPA and two carboxylate oxygens from acetate to form a Cu(OH)O4 square pyramid. The structure of I has the μ3-hydroxyl ions connecting with the copper centers to form a one-dimensional zigzag Cu–O(H)–Cu chain structure, which are bonded with the carboxylate and acetate units giving rise to the two-dimensional structure () (Figure ).

Results and Discussion

Structure of [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I 

The asymmetric unit of [Cu3(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}(CH3COO)], I, consists of 27 non-hydrogen atoms. Three crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions along with one sulphoisophthalate (SIPA), one acetate, two μ3-hydroxyl groups, and two coordinated water molecule contribute to the asymmetric unit (). All the Cu2+ ions have distorted square-pyramidal coordination; Cu(1) is coordinated by three μ3-hydroxyl ion, one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA, and one carboxylate oxygen from acetate to form a Cu(OH)3O2 square pyramid; Cu(2) is coordinated by two μ3-hydroxyl ion, two aqua oxygens, and one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA to form a Cu(OH)2(H2O)2O square pyramid; Cu(3) is coordinated by a μ3-hydroxyl ion, two carboxylate oxygens from SIPA and two carboxylate oxygens from acetate to form a Cu(OH)O4 square pyramid. The structure of I has the μ3-hydroxyl ions connecting with the copper centers to form a one-dimensional zigzag Cu-O(H)-Cu chain structure, which are bonded with the carboxylate and acetate units giving rise to the two-dimensional structure () (Figure ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of [Cu5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4].5H2O, II, consists of 40 non-hydrogen atoms, of which three Cu2+ ions are crystallographically independent along with two 5-nitroisophthalate (NIPA), one μ3-hydroxyl groups, three coordinated water molecules, and three lattice water molecules (). Of these, one Cu2+ ion, Cu(1), and a lattice water molecule, O(100), occupies a special position (1e and 1b) with a site multiplicity of 0.5. While Cu(1) has a octahedral coordination, Cu(2) and Cu(3) have square-pyramidal coordination. The copper atoms are connected through two μ3-OH and a μ2-H2O forming a pentameric cluster (). The nitroisophthalate units are connected with the Cu5 clusters giving rise to the observed three-dimensional structure () (Figure ).

Of these, one Cu2+ ion, Cu(1), and a lattice water molecule, O(100), occupies a special position (1e and 1b) with a site multiplicity of 0.5. While Cu(1) has a octahedral coordination, Cu(2) and Cu(3) have square-pyramidal coordination. The copper atoms are connected through two μ3-OH and a μ2-H2O forming a pentameric cluster (). The nitroisophthalate units are connected with the Cu5 clusters giving rise to the observed three-dimensional structure () (Figure ).

elements.content: As can be noted, I has two coordinated water molecules. The TGA studies indicated that the water molecules are removed around 180–230 °C and the dehydrated phase appeared to be stable up to 280 °C. It occurred to us that one could investigate the dehydrated phase, if possible in the single crystalline phase, under in situ conditions. Such studies would reveal the dynamics of the removal of water molecules and provide vital clues toward the structural integrity and stability. The solvent removal, exchange, and dimensionalitity changes of MOFs have been investigated through SCSC transformations. We have, thus, carried out in situ SCSC transformation studies. It was observed that the dehydrated structure, Ia, is totally different from the original structure. We also observed a change in the overall dimensionality as well. The dehydrated compound, Ia, is a three-dimensional compound, whereas the parent compound, I, was a two-dimensional one. Compound II contains two coordinated water molecule, which appears to be leaving around 150 °C, as revealed by the TGA studies. An in situ SCSC study indicated that the dehydrated structure, IIa, exhibited differences due to structural reorganization.
elements.clean_text:
In Situ Single Crystal to Single Crystal (SCSC) Transformation Studies

As can be noted, I has two coordinated water molecules. The TGA studies indicated that the water molecules are removed around 180-230 °C and the dehydrated phase appeared to be stable up to 280 °C. It occurred to us that one could investigate the dehydrated phase, if possible in the single crystalline phase, under in situ conditions. Such studies would reveal the dynamics of the removal of water molecules and provide vital clues toward the structural integrity and stability. The solvent removal, exchange, and dimensionalitity changes of MOFs have been investigated through SCSC transformations. We have, thus, carried out in situ SCSC transformation studies. It was observed that the dehydrated structure, Ia, is totally different from the original structure. We also observed a change in the overall dimensionality as well. The dehydrated compound, Ia, is a three-dimensional compound, whereas the parent compound, I, was a two-dimensional one. Compound II contains two coordinated water molecule, which appears to be leaving around 150 °C, as revealed by the TGA studies. An in situ SCSC study indicated that the dehydrated structure, IIa, exhibited differences due to structural reorganization.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of [Cu6(μ3-OH)4{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}2(CH3COO)2], Ia, consists of 50 non-hydrogen atoms. Six crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions along with two sulphoisophthalate (SIPA), two acetate and four μ3-hydroxyl groups contribute to the asymmetric unit (). All the Cu2+ ions have distorted square-pyramidal coordination; Cu(1) and Cu(4) are coordinated by two μ3-hydroxyl ions, one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA, one carboxylate oxygen from acetate, and one oxygen from sulfonate group of SIPA to form a Cu(OH)2O3 square pyramid; Cu(2) and Cu(6) are coordinated by three μ3-hydroxyl ions, one carboxylate oxygen from SIPA, and one oxygen from sulfonate group to form a Cu(OH)3O2 square pyramid; Cu(3) and Cu(5) are coordinated by a μ3-hydroxyl ion, two carboxylate oxygens from SIPA, and two carboxylate oxygens from acetate to form a Cu(OH)O4 square pyramid. The Cu–O bonds have distances in the range 1.900(8)–2.362(9)Å (av. 2.022 Å), and the O–Cu–O bond angles are in the range of 77.8(4)–177.2(4)° for Ia (Table ).

The Cu-O bonds have distances in the range 1.900(8)-2.362(9)Å (av. 2.022 Å), and the O-Cu-O bond angles are in the range of 77.8(4)-177.2(4)° for Ia (Table ).

The structure of Ia has μ3-hydroxyl ions connecting the copper centers. Thus, Cu(1), Cu(2), Cu(4), and Cu(6) are connected to form a tetrameric unit. The Cu4 tetramers are connected on either side by the Cu(3) and Cu(5) dimers to give rise to a one-dimensional Cu–O–Cu chain structure (Figure a). The bonding of the two acetate moieties, however, are different in Ia; while one acetate unit has a connectivity similar to that present in I (), the second acetate unit is bonded to four copper centers (). In addition, we observed that the bonding of the sulfonate oxygens is different. Of the two SIPA acids, SIPA(1) connects the Cu–O–Cu chains to form a two-dimensional layer (Figure b). The other acid, SIPA(2), however, exhibits both in-plane as well as out-of-plane connectivity. This, in fact, gives rise to the three-dimensional structure. This is possible due to the participation of the second oxygen from the sulfonate group in SIPA(2) in bonding with the copper center with the neighboring layer (Figure c) (). It may be noted that the layers observed in I and Ia are similar. The differences between the structure arises due to the bonding behavior of the acetate moiety as well as the second acid, SIPA(2). On removing the bound water, one of the acetate units in Ia binds with the neighboring copper, thus binding with four copper centers (). The sulfonate oxygen is also bonded to Cu(2) in place of the water molecule ().

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, consists of 34 non-hydrogen atoms, of which three Cu2+ ions are crystallographically independent along with two 5-nitroisophthalate (NIPA) and one μ2-hydroxyl group (). Cu(1) has an octahedral coordination and occupies a special position (1e) with a site multiplicity of 0.5, similar to the parent structure. Cu(2) has a distorted square pyramidal and Cu(3) has a distorted tetrahedral coordination with respect to their oxygen neighbors. The marked changes observed in the coordination around the copper centers are due to the removal of the coordinated water molecule (). The Cu–O distances are in the range of 1.875(3)–2.624(3) Å (av. Cu(1)–O = 2.166, Cu(2)–O = 2.070, Cu(3)–O = 1.927 Å). The longer Cu–O distances are associated with the carboxylate oxygen that replaces the H2O molecule (Table ). The Cu–O bond angles are in the range 88.81(13)–180.0(3) in IIa.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa 

The asymmetric unit of [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, consists of 34 non-hydrogen atoms, of which three Cu2+ ions are crystallographically independent along with two 5-nitroisophthalate (NIPA) and one μ2-hydroxyl group (). Cu(1) has an octahedral coordination and occupies a special position (1e) with a site multiplicity of 0.5, similar to the parent structure. Cu(2) has a distorted square pyramidal and Cu(3) has a distorted tetrahedral coordination with respect to their oxygen neighbors. The marked changes observed in the coordination around the copper centers are due to the removal of the coordinated water molecule (). The Cu-O distances are in the range of 1.875(3)-2.624(3) Å (av. Cu(1)-O = 2.166, Cu(2)-O = 2.070, Cu(3)-O = 1.927 Å). The longer Cu-O distances are associated with the carboxylate oxygen that replaces the H2O molecule (Table ). The Cu-O bond angles are in the range 88.81(13)-180.0(3) in IIa.

elements.content: Of the two acids, the NIPA(1) unit is connected to four Cu2+ ions through the carboxylate oxygen and the nitro group remains nonbonded (), while the NIPA(2) is connected to five Cu2+ ions through both the carboxylate as well as the nitro group oxygen atoms (). The μ2-OH connects one Cu(1) and two Cu(3) to form a trimeric copper cluster (Cu3O12). Two Cu(2) centers are connected through the three-coordinated oxygen atoms (oxygen connecting two copper centers and a carbon) forming a dimer (Cu2O8) (Figure a,b). The connectivity of the NIPA(1) along with the Cu3O12 and Cu2O8 clusters results in a two-dimensional layer in the ac plane (Figure c). These trimeric and dimeric clusters are also connected by the NIPA(2), and the participation of the nitro group results in the three-dimensional structure (Figure a,b) ().

elements.content: The structure of IIa can also be described as having a one-dimensional Cu–O–Cu chain, if the secondary coordination sphere for the copper can be considered. It is likely that the loss of coordinated water molecules would result in newer interactions, and thus the longer Cu–O bond, Cu(2)–O(8) = 2.831(6) Å, could involve in bonding type interactions. This interaction could connect the dimeric and the trimric copper clusters forming a one-dimensional Cu–O–Cu chain (). The one-dimensional chains could be subsequently connected by the two acids, NIPA(1) and NIPA(2), forming the three-dimensional structure.

elements.content: We have also carried out in situ temperature-dependent powder X-ray diffraction studies to investigate the structural transformation in both compounds (Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with an Anton Parr HTK 16 high-temperature stage and a Braun Position Sensitive Detector). The sample was carefully placed over a tantalum heating strip and heated in air up to 300 °C. Data were collected over an angular range of 8–50 (2θ) with a resolution of 0.019° at 1.00 s/step. The results of this study are summarized in Figure a,b. As can be noted, the temperature-dependent PXRD studies also confirm that I is stable up to 110 °C, after which Ia starts to appear. At 230 °C, the formation of Ia is complete. In the case of II, the structural reorganization starts to take place ∼80 °C and the transformation is completed at 140 °C. More importantly, IIa appears to remain crystalline up to 300 °C. Further heating, however, decomposes the compounds leading to the formation of CuO.
elements.clean_text:
In-situ Temperature Dependent Powder-X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Thermogravimetric Studies

We have also carried out in situ temperature-dependent powder X-ray diffraction studies to investigate the structural transformation in both compounds (Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with an Anton Parr HTK 16 high-temperature stage and a Braun Position Sensitive Detector). The sample was carefully placed over a tantalum heating strip and heated in air up to 300 °C. Data were collected over an angular range of 8-50 (2θ) with a resolution of 0.019° at 1.00 s/step. The results of this study are summarized in Figure a,b. As can be noted, the temperature-dependent PXRD studies also confirm that I is stable up to 110 °C, after which Ia starts to appear. At 230 °C, the formation of Ia is complete. In the case of II, the structural reorganization starts to take place ~80 °C and the transformation is completed at 140 °C. More importantly, IIa appears to remain crystalline up to 300 °C. Further heating, however, decomposes the compounds leading to the formation of CuO.

elements.content: As mentioned earlier, the TGA studies of I and II indicated the loss of water molecules below ∼180 °C (). This observation prompted us to examine the possibility of reversibly adsorbing the water molecules in the transformed structure. Our SCSC transformation studies also suggested that the dehydrated sample, Ia, rehydrates quickly to form I on cooling to room temperature. We wanted to examine the recyclability of the rehydration/hydration process. The reversibility of water adsorption was carried out in a modified TGA setup containing a port for introducing the water vapor. The sample was taken in the TGA crucible and heated to temperature of complete dehydration in an atmosphere of flowing dry nitrogen (50 mL/min) (210 °C for I and 140 °C for II) using a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The sample was cooled slowly to room temperature (cooling rate = 2 °C/min for I and 1 °C/min for II) and saturated water vapor was introduced into the system for rehydration for 60 and 180 min, respectively. During this process, we observed that both samples reabsorbed the water molecules and reached close to the original weights. Thus, 98.3% of the initial weight was absorbed from the dehydrated weights of 92.5% in the case of I. For II, 96.5% of the initial weight was observed from the dehydrated weight of 87.4%. Complete absorption of water molecules was observed when the samples were exposed to atmospheric conditions for a longer duration. This process of dehydration–rehydration was repeated two times, which confirmed the recyclability (Figure a,b). A PXRD investigation on the rehydrated samples also confirmed that the integrity of the samples was maintained.

elements.content: From the above studies, it appears that the removal of coordinated water molecules from the copper centers holds the clue for understanding of transformations. The two copper atoms, Cu(1) and Cu(2), change the coordination during the transformation of I → Ia, while the third copper, Cu(3), is not affected. The Cu(2) centers are bonded with two coordinated water molecules and could play an important role. In addition, the role of the bonded acetate units are also crucial. On the basis of the observation of the structures of I and Ia, one can propose and consider a possible pathway involving two distinct steps (Figure a). In the first step, the removal of the coordinated water molecules allows the nonbonded sulfonate oxygens (one intralayer and one interlayer) to bind with the Cu(2) centers (the pathway is marked red). In the next step, the intralayer sulfonate oxygens bind with Cu(1), which in turns allows the acetate units to bind with Cu(2). The second acetate moiety remains bonded to both the Cu(1) and the Cu(2) sites (marked in green). Here the participation of the sulfonte units in bonding makes the dimensionality cross-over in the structure. The entire transformation is facile and takes place simultaneously.
elements.clean_text:
Understanding the Transformations in I and II 

From the above studies, it appears that the removal of coordinated water molecules from the copper centers holds the clue for understanding of transformations. The two copper atoms, Cu(1) and Cu(2), change the coordination during the transformation of I → Ia, while the third copper, Cu(3), is not affected. The Cu(2) centers are bonded with two coordinated water molecules and could play an important role. In addition, the role of the bonded acetate units are also crucial. On the basis of the observation of the structures of I and Ia, one can propose and consider a possible pathway involving two distinct steps (Figure a). In the first step, the removal of the coordinated water molecules allows the nonbonded sulfonate oxygens (one intralayer and one interlayer) to bind with the Cu(2) centers (the pathway is marked red). In the next step, the intralayer sulfonate oxygens bind with Cu(1), which in turns allows the acetate units to bind with Cu(2). The second acetate moiety remains bonded to both the Cu(1) and the Cu(2) sites (marked in green). Here the participation of the sulfonte units in bonding makes the dimensionality cross-over in the structure. The entire transformation is facile and takes place simultaneously.

elements.content: In the case of the transformation of II to IIa, all the three copper centers participate in the structural reorganization. During the transformation, the pentameric copper clusters of II split into trimeric (Cu3O12) and dimeric (Cu2O8) copper clusters in IIa. This suggests that the structure needs to undergo considerable structural reorganization. A careful examination of the structure of IIa suggests three possible steps for the structural reorganization, possibly occurring simultaneously (Figure b). In the first step, the removal of the water molecule allows the carboxylate oxygen, O(4), to bridge the Cu(2) centers forming a dimer (marked in green). In the second step, the free carboxylate oxygen binds the Cu(2) and Cu(3) centers. This step is also accompanied by the removal of one coordinated water molecule and a change in the bonding of the OH unit from a μ3- to a μ2-bridging mode (marked in red). In the final step, the Cu(1) centers gets interconnected to two Cu(2) sites with two free carboxylate oxygen and facilitates the removal of two coordinated water molecules (marked in blue). Thus, in the transformation, Cu(2) centers acts as the connector between the clusters, whereas Cu(1) and Cu(3) takes part in the internal reorganization of the cluster.

elements.content: The two compounds, I and II, have been formed from similar acids. It has been known that the sulpho group, in general, does not participate actively in the formation of framework structures. This resulted in a two-dimensional structure for I, whereas the nitro group bonds with the copper centers in II resulting in a three-dimensional structure. As can be noted, the synthesis conditions for the preparation of I and II are similar. We believe that the lack of reactivity of the sulpho group is responsible for the observed structure of I. This behavior of the sulpho group was altered during the heating of the sample. The free sulfonate group was activated, possibly due to the higher temperature, resulting in the dimensionality cross-over in Ia. On the contrary, the nitro group already being bonded as part of the structure of II, only a structural reorganization was observed during the heating of II.

elements.content: Studies probing such transformations have not been common in the literature. The pathways for the transformations outlined here are only a possible clue to what could happen during the dehydration of the compounds, I and II, on heating. It is difficult to follow and understand solid state transformations, especially involving dimensionality cross-over (I → Ia) and structural reorganization (II → IIa). We have outlined in Figure the possible pathways based on the observation of the initial and final structures of the compounds along with our understanding of the dynamics of the water removal. The mechanistic pathways outlined here provide us with reasonable insights that are necessary to obtain better control of the structures. Similar mechanistic pathways have been proposed earlier for the transformation of the structures of lower dimensionality to higher ones in the family of phosphates.

elements.content: The transformation studies revealed that Ia was a transient phase and appears to revert back to I even during the cooling of the sample. In order to perform further characterizations, the sample of Ia was carefully prepared by heating the sample and transferring it inside a glovebox. At room temperature, the χM T value of I is 1.42 emu mol–l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol–l K for S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is a slightly higher than expected value for three noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For Ia, the χM T values at room temperature was found to be lower, 1.36 emu mol–l K. The χM T values for both I and Ia were found to decrease continuously and reach a similar value of 0.083 (I and Ia) at 3.5 K (Figure a). A Curie–Weiss fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 100–300 K gave values of C = 1.53 emu/mol and θP = −22.7 K for I, and C = 1.47 emu/mol and θP = −25.2 K for Ia, respectively (). The near identical behavior of I and Ia indicated that exchanges between the neighboring Cu–O–Cu chains (5.96 Å apart) connected by the O–S–O bridges in both compounds are similar.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The transformation studies revealed that Ia was a transient phase and appears to revert back to I even during the cooling of the sample. In order to perform further characterizations, the sample of Ia was carefully prepared by heating the sample and transferring it inside a glovebox. At room temperature, the χM T value of I is 1.42 emu mol-l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol-l K for S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is a slightly higher than expected value for three noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For Ia, the χM T values at room temperature was found to be lower, 1.36 emu mol-l K. The χM T values for both I and Ia were found to decrease continuously and reach a similar value of 0.083 (I and Ia) at 3.5 K (Figure a). A Curie-Weiss fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 100-300 K gave values of C = 1.53 emu/mol and θP = -22.7 K for I, and C = 1.47 emu/mol and θP = -25.2 K for Ia, respectively (). The near identical behavior of I and Ia indicated that exchanges between the neighboring Cu-O-Cu chains (5.96 Å apart) connected by the O-S-O bridges in both compounds are similar.

elements.content: Compound IIa, on the other hand, was found to be more stable at room temperature. We have carried out detailed magnetic studies of both II and IIa. At room temperature, the χM T value of II is 1.88 emu mol–l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol–l K for a S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is equal to the expected value for five noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For IIa, the χM T values at room temperature are found to be marginally higher, 1.94 emu mol–l K. The χM T values of II and IIa were found to decrease continuously to a value of 0.420 (II) and 0.643 (IIa) at 3.5 K (Figure b). A fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 50–300 K for the Curie–Weiss behavior gave a value for C = 2.51 emu/mol and θP = −93.4 K for II, and C = 2.04 emu/mol and θP = −11.1K for IIa, respectively (). The high negative value of θP for II suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers are strongly antiferromagnetic. The lower value of θP for IIa suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers, though still antiferrmagnetic, are weaker compared to II.
elements.clean_text: Compound IIa, on the other hand, was found to be more stable at room temperature. We have carried out detailed magnetic studies of both II and IIa. At room temperature, the χM T value of II is 1.88 emu mol-l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol-l K for a S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is equal to the expected value for five noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For IIa, the χM T values at room temperature are found to be marginally higher, 1.94 emu mol-l K. The χM T values of II and IIa were found to decrease continuously to a value of 0.420 (II) and 0.643 (IIa) at 3.5 K (Figure b). A fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 50-300 K for the Curie-Weiss behavior gave a value for C = 2.51 emu/mol and θP = -93.4 K for II, and C = 2.04 emu/mol and θP = -11.1K for IIa, respectively (). The high negative value of θP for II suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers are strongly antiferromagnetic. The lower value of θP for IIa suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers, though still antiferrmagnetic, are weaker compared to II.

elements.content: The transformed compounds, Ia nd IIa, exhibit different magnetic behaviors. In Ia, though there is a dimensionality cross-over, the magnetic centers (Cu–O–Cu one-dimensional chains) are not affected. In IIa, however, the pentameric clusters observed in II were changed into trimeric (Cu3O12) and dimeric (Cu2O8) copper clusters in IIa. In addition, there are also changes in the coordination around the copper centers. The structural changes need careful consideration in arriving at a possible explanation for the reduced antiferrmagnetic exchanges in IIa. Thus, during the transformation the μ3-OH became μ2-OH, which resulted in an increase in the distances between the Cu(1) and the Cu(2) centers (from 3.507 to 5.211 Å), while the other Cu–Cu distances, Cu(1) and Cu(3) and Cu(2) and Cu(3), are not affected much. The bond angles between the copper centers, Cu(1)–O(1)–Cu(3) (113.6°) and Cu2-dimer angle, Cu(2)–O(4) −Cu(2) (98.2°) are suggestive of ferromagnetic correlation between the copper centers. It is conceivable that the combined effects of changes in the distances, angles, and coordination resulted in reduced antiferromagnetic interactions between the copper centers in IIa. Similar observations have been made earlier. This study, thus, suggests that one can possibly tune the magnetic behavior/interactions between the participating metal ions by carefully modifying the coordination environment.

elements.content: In conclusion, the in situ single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation studies have been employed for the study of structural transformation and rearrangement in copper-containing MOFs. The studies suggest the formation of a transient highly unstable three-dimensional structure in [Cu6(μ3-OH)4{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}2(CH3COO)2], Ia, and a structural rearrangement within the structure in [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, the changes being brought about by the removal of the coordinated water molecules from the copper centers. The transient nature of the three-dimensional compound was also examined by temperature dependent PXRD studies. TGA analysis employing a modified setup indicated that the removal/insertion of water molecules is completely reversible. The above studies suggest that the water molecules in the investigated copper containing MOFs are labile. On the basis of the studies, a possible model for such transformation has been proposed. Magnetic studies indicate that the interactions between the copper centers are much weaker in the dehydrated state.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, the in situ single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation studies have been employed for the study of structural transformation and rearrangement in copper-containing MOFs. The studies suggest the formation of a transient highly unstable three-dimensional structure in [Cu6(μ3-OH)4{(SO3)-C6H3-(COO)2}2(CH3COO)2], Ia, and a structural rearrangement within the structure in [Cu5(μ2-OH)2{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4], IIa, the changes being brought about by the removal of the coordinated water molecules from the copper centers. The transient nature of the three-dimensional compound was also examined by temperature dependent PXRD studies. TGA analysis employing a modified setup indicated that the removal/insertion of water molecules is completely reversible. The above studies suggest that the water molecules in the investigated copper containing MOFs are labile. On the basis of the studies, a possible model for such transformation has been proposed. Magnetic studies indicate that the interactions between the copper centers are much weaker in the dehydrated state.

cln_elements.content: The compounds were prepared by employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for I, Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.199 g, 1 mM) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. To this, 5-sulphoisophthalic acid (0.268 g, 1 mM), melamine (0.042 g, 0.25 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture was transferred, sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave, and heated at 125 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The final product contained large quantities of green block type single crystals, which were filtered under a vacuum, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ∼70% based on Cu). For the synthesis of II, a mixture containing Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.060 g, 0.3 mM), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mM), 3 mL of methanol, and 5 mL of water was heated in a PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave at 125 °C for 72 h to give light blue crystals of II (the yield was ∼73% based on Cu).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Initial Characterization

The compounds were prepared by employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for I, Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (0.199 g, 1 mM) was dissolved in 10 mL of water. To this, 5-sulphoisophthalic acid (0.268 g, 1 mM), melamine (0.042 g, 0.25 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture was transferred, sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave, and heated at 125 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. The final product contained large quantities of green block type single crystals, which were filtered under a vacuum, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ~70% based on Cu). For the synthesis of II, a mixture containing Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (0.060 g, 0.3 mM), 5-nitroisophthalic acid (0.042 g, 0.2 mM), 3 mL of methanol, and 5 mL of water was heated in a PTFE-lined stainless steel autoclave at 125 °C for 72 h to give light blue crystals of II (the yield was ~73% based on Cu).

cln_elements.content:
The asymmetric unit of [Cu5(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6{(NO2)-C6H3-(COO)2}4].5H2O, II, consists of 40 non-hydrogen atoms, of which three Cu2+ ions are crystallographically independent along with two 5-nitroisophthalate (NIPA), one μ3-hydroxyl groups, three coordinated water molecules, and three lattice water molecules (). Of these, one Cu2+ ion, Cu(1), and a lattice water molecule, O(100), occupies a special position (1e and 1b) with a site multiplicity of 0.5. While Cu(1) has a octahedral coordination, Cu(2) and Cu(3) have square-pyramidal coordination. The copper atoms are connected through two μ3-OH and a μ2-H2O forming a pentameric cluster (). The nitroisophthalate units are connected with the Cu5 clusters giving rise to the observed three-dimensional structure () (Figure ).

Magnetic Studies

The transformation studies revealed that Ia was a transient phase and appears to revert back to I even during the cooling of the sample. In order to perform further characterizations, the sample of Ia was carefully prepared by heating the sample and transferring it inside a glovebox. At room temperature, the χM T value of I is 1.42 emu mol–l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol–l K for S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is a slightly higher than expected value for three noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For Ia, the χM T values at room temperature was found to be lower, 1.36 emu mol–l K. The χM T values for both I and Ia were found to decrease continuously and reach a similar value of 0.083 (I and Ia) at 3.5 K (Figure a). A Curie–Weiss fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 100–300 K gave values of C = 1.53 emu/mol and θP = −22.7 K for I, and C = 1.47 emu/mol and θP = −25.2 K for Ia, respectively (). The near identical behavior of I and Ia indicated that exchanges between the neighboring Cu–O–Cu chains (5.96 Å apart) connected by the O–S–O bridges in both compounds are similar.

Compound IIa, on the other hand, was found to be more stable at room temperature. We have carried out detailed magnetic studies of both II and IIa. At room temperature, the χM T value of II is 1.88 emu mol–l K (χM T = 0.375 emu mol–l K for a S = 1/2 system, single Cu2+ ions), which is equal to the expected value for five noncoupled Cu2+ ions. For IIa, the χM T values at room temperature are found to be marginally higher, 1.94 emu mol–l K. The χM T values of II and IIa were found to decrease continuously to a value of 0.420 (II) and 0.643 (IIa) at 3.5 K (Figure b). A fit of the 1/χM vs T data in the temperature range 50–300 K for the Curie–Weiss behavior gave a value for C = 2.51 emu/mol and θP = −93.4 K for II, and C = 2.04 emu/mol and θP = −11.1K for IIa, respectively (). The high negative value of θP for II suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers are strongly antiferromagnetic. The lower value of θP for IIa suggests that the exchanges between the copper centers, though still antiferrmagnetic, are weaker compared to II.

metadata.title: Usefulness of in Situ Single Crystal to Single Crystal Transformation (SCSC) Studies in Understanding the Temperature-Dependent Dimensionality Cross-over and Structural Reorganization in Copper-Containing Metal–Organic Frameworks (MOFs)
